6. Let $X=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $\mathrm{E}\|X\|^{n}<\infty$, where $\|X\|=\sqrt{\sum X_{i}^{2}}$. Show that

$$
\varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} e^{i(t, X)}=\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} \mathrm{E}(t, X)^{k}}{k!}+o(1) \cdot\|t\|^{n}, \quad\|t\| \rightarrow 0
$$

where $t \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$.
original.solution:
Solution. By expanding $\cos x$ and $\sin x$ into a sum of powers of $x$ with the remainder term in the form of Taylor, one can obtain various upper bounds for the modulus of the difference

$$
\left|e^{i x}-\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} x^{k}}{k!}\right|
$$

valid for any real $x$. For example, estimate it by $3|x|^{n+1}, 3|x|^{n}$, and thus $3|x|^{n} \cdot|x| \wedge 1$. But then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\varphi(t)-\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} \mathrm{E}(t, X)^{k}}{k!}\right| \leqslant 3 \mathrm{E}\left[|(t, X)|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)|\right. & \wedge 1] \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 3\|t\|^{n} \mathrm{E}\left[\|X\|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)| \wedge 1\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to note that $\mathrm{E}\left[\|X\|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)| \wedge 1\right] \rightarrow 0$ as $\|t\| \rightarrow 0$ by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem.

16. Show that in the space

$$
L^{2}=L^{2}([-\pi, \pi], \mathscr{B}([-\pi, \pi]))
$$

with the Lebesgue measure, the system of functions $\left\{\frac{e^{i \lambda n}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ forms an orthonormal basis.
original.solution:
Solution. The proof can be carried out according to the following scheme:

(a) for $\varepsilon>0$, find some $c>0$ such that

$$
\|\varphi-f\|_{L^{2}}<\varepsilon, \quad f(x)=\varphi(x) I(|\varphi(x)| \leqslant c)
$$

(b) by the Lusin's theorem (see problem II.10.35), find a continuous function $f_{\varepsilon}(x)$ such that $|f_{\varepsilon}(x)| \leqslant c$ and

$$
\mu\left\{x \in[-\pi, \pi]: f_{\varepsilon}(x) \neq f(x)\right\}<\varepsilon
$$

then $\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant 2 c \sqrt{\varepsilon}$

(c) find a continuous function $g_{\varepsilon}(x)$ such that $g_{\varepsilon}(-\pi)=g_{\varepsilon}(\pi)$ and $\left\|g_{\varepsilon}-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant \varepsilon ;$

(d) by the Weierstrass theorem, find a function

$$
h_{\varepsilon}(x)=\sum_{k=-n}^{n} a_{k} e^{i k x}
$$

such that

$$
\sup _{x \in[-\pi, \pi]}\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-h_{\varepsilon}(x)\right| \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

and, therefore, $\left\|g_{\varepsilon}-h_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant \varepsilon$.

From (a)-(d), it follows that finite sums of the form $\sum_{k=-n}^{n} a_{k} e^{i k x}$ form a dense set in $L^{2}$, i.e., the system $\left\{\frac{e^{i \lambda n}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ forms an (orthonormal) basis.

original.problem:
75. (See [49].) Let $\left\{X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots\right\}$ be a uniformly integrable family of random variables. Show that (as $n \rightarrow \infty$)

$$
X_{n} \xrightarrow{d} \mathscr{N}(0,1) \Leftrightarrow \mathrm{E}\left[X_{n} e^{i t X_{n}}-i t e^{i t X_{n}}\right] \rightarrow 0 \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R} .
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The family of random variables $\left\{X_{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ is tight, since

$$
\sup _{n} \mathrm{P}\left(\varepsilon\left|X_{n}\right|>1\right) \leqslant \sup _{n} \varepsilon \mathrm{E}\left|X_{n}\right| I\left(\varepsilon\left|X_{n}\right|>1\right) \rightarrow 0, \quad \varepsilon \downarrow 0 .
$$

Therefore, by Prokhorov's theorem, it is relatively compact, i.e., from any sequence $\left(n^{\prime}\right) \subset(n)$ one can extract a subsequence $\left(n^{\prime \prime}\right) \subset\left(n^{\prime}\right)$, for which $X_{n^{\prime \prime}}$ converge in distribution to some random variable $X$ as $n^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow \infty$.

Thus, it suffices to check that any such $X$ is distributed according to the law $\mathscr{N}(0,1)$. We have

$$
\varphi^{\prime}(t)+t \varphi(t)=0, \quad \varphi(0)=1
$$

where $\varphi$ is the characteristic function of the random variable $X$. Indeed, due to the uniform integrability of $X_{n}$, we have

$$
\lim _{n} \mathrm{E}\left[i X_{n} e^{i t X_{n}}+t e^{i t X_{n}}\right]=0=\mathrm{E}\left[i X e^{i t X}+t e^{i t X}\right]=\varphi^{\prime}(t)+t \varphi(t) .
$$

The only solution to the given differential equation is $\varphi(t)=$ $=e^{-t^{2} / 2}$, i.e., $X \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$.

The converse statement is proved similarly.

llm_response:
This problem is a statement regarding the convergence of a sequence of random variables and involves proving a theorem related to convergence in distribution and characteristic functions. The solution requires a detailed argument involving properties of uniformly integrable families and the application of Prokhorov's theorem.

Given that the task is to demonstrate an implication of convergence and the use of specific properties rather than simply compute a derivative or evaluate a limit, this problem fits the category of needing to prove a property rather than performing a straight computation.

Therefore, I classify this problem as:

HARD: The solution involves proving properties of characteristic functions and their relationship to convergence in distribution, rather than straightforward computation.

original.problem:
70. (See [103].) Let the function $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow(0, \infty)$ be smooth up to the second order, and for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, the following equality holds:

$$
\nabla^{2} h(x)=\nabla^{\top} \nabla h(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d} h_{x_{i} x_{i}}^{\prime \prime}(x) \leqslant 0, \quad h=\sqrt{f}
$$

Also,

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\nabla \ln f(\xi)\|^{2}<\infty, \quad \mathrm{E} \frac{1}{f(\xi)} \sum_{i=1}^{d} f_{x_{i} x_{i}}^{\prime \prime}(\xi)<\infty
$$

where $\xi$ is a Gaussian vector in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with the identity covariance matrix, and

$$
\nabla=\left(\nabla_{1}, \ldots, \nabla_{d}\right), \quad \nabla_{i}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}
$$

Prove that, regardless of $\mathrm{E} \xi$, the following inequality holds:

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2} \leqslant \mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d
$$

Also derive that for $d \geqslant 3$, the following equalities hold:

$$
\mathrm{E}\left\|\xi+\frac{A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-\mathrm{E} \xi\right\|^{2}=d-\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}, \quad B=[(\operatorname{tr} A) I-2 A]^{-1} A^{2}
$$

for any symmetric matrix $A$ such that the matrix $(\operatorname{tr} A) I-2 A$ is positive definite.
original.solution:
Solution. We have

$\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=$

$$
=\mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}+2 \mathrm{E}(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} \nabla \ln f(\xi)+\mathrm{E}\|\nabla \ln f(\xi)\|^{2}
$$

and by problem II.13.68 we obtain

$$
\mathrm{E}(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} \nabla \ln f(\xi)=\mathrm{E} \nabla^{2} \ln f(\xi)
$$

Moreover,

$$
\nabla^{2} \ln f=\nabla^{\top} \frac{\nabla f}{f}=\frac{\nabla^{2} f}{f}-\frac{\|\nabla f\|^{2}}{f^{2}}
$$

thus,

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d+2 \mathrm{E} \frac{\nabla^{2} f(\xi)}{f(\xi)}-\mathrm{E} \frac{\|\nabla f(\xi)\|^{2}}{f(\xi)^{2}}
$$

Noting now that

$$
\nabla^{2} \sqrt{f}=\nabla^{\top} \nabla \sqrt{f}=\frac{1}{2} \nabla^{\top} \frac{\nabla f}{\sqrt{f}}=\frac{\nabla^{2} f}{2 \sqrt{f}}-\frac{\|\nabla f\|^{2}}{4 f^{3 / 2}}
$$

we finally obtain

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d+4 \mathrm{E} \frac{\nabla^{2} \sqrt{f}(\xi)}{\sqrt{f}(\xi)} \leqslant d
$$

Let's move on to the second part of the problem. By problem II.13.69, all the expectations mentioned below exist (for $d \geqslant 3$). We have

$$
\mathrm{E}\left\|\xi+\frac{A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-\mathrm{E} \xi\right\|^{2}=\mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}+2 \mathrm{E} \frac{(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}+\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}} .
$$

By Stein's lemma (see problem II.13.68)

$$
\mathrm{E} \frac{(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}=\mathrm{E} \frac{\operatorname{tr} A}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-2 \mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A B \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}=-\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}
$$

From this, the desired equality follows.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a specific inequality and deriving additional equalities related to properties of a smooth function \( f \) and its derivatives, with the context of expectations in multivariate statistics. It requires understanding the implications of properties of derivatives and applying tools like Stein's lemma. This does not reduce to merely executing a computation; rather, it needs a careful proof to establish the relationships.

Thus, I classify this problem as:

HARD

The justification is that proving the inequality and deriving the equalities requires handling the properties of the function and its derivatives systematically, which goes beyond straightforward computation.

original.problem:
114. Prove that as $x \rightarrow 0$:
1) $\sin a x \approx a x$; 2) $\tan a x \approx a x$; 3) $\arcsin a x \approx a x$;
2) $\arctan a x \approx a x$
3) $\sqrt{1+x}-1 \approx \frac{1}{2} x$
original.solution:
Solution. To prove the equivalence of two infinitesimals, we need to find the limit of their ratio. If this limit turns out to be equal to one, then the infinitesimals are equivalent.

1) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x}=\lim _{a x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x}=1\).
2) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{tg} a x}{a x}=\lim \frac{\sin a x}{a x \cos a x}=\lim _{a x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x} \cdot \lim \frac{1}{\cos a x}=1 \cdot 1=1\).
3) Let \(\operatorname{arcšin} a x=\alpha\), then we get:

\[
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\arcsin a x}{a x}=\lim _{a \rightarrow 0} \frac{a}{\sin \alpha}=1
\]

4) Let \(\operatorname{arctg} a x=z\), then we find:

\[
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{arctg} \alpha x}{\operatorname{ax}}=\lim _{z \rightarrow 0} \frac{z}{\operatorname{tg} z}=\lim \frac{z}{\sin z} \lim \cos z=1
\]

5) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+x}-1}{\frac{x}{2}}=2 \lim \frac{1+x-1}{x(\sqrt{1+x}+1)}=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2}=1\).

llm_response:
This problem involves proving approximations of trigonometric and square root functions as \( x \) approaches \( 0 \). The solution requires calculating limits to show that the ratios of the functions in question converge to \( 1 \), establishing their equivalence as \( x \) approaches \( 0 \). 

This characterizes the problem as one that involves proving properties of functions rather than simply executing computations or verifying identities. Hence it requires a significant level of rigor.

Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

HARD: The solution requires proving properties of functions through limits, which involves understanding behavior at infinity and determining equivalence.

original.problem:
264. The speed of a body in rectilinear motion is proportional to the square root of the distance traveled (as, for example, 
in free fall). Prove that this motion occurs under the action of a constant force.
original.solution:
Solution. According to Newton's law, the force $F$ causing the motion is proportional to the acceleration

$$
F=k \frac{d^{2} s}{d t^{2}}
$$

According to the condition $\frac{d s}{d t}=\lambda \sqrt{s}$. Differentiating this equality, we find

$$
\frac{d^{2} s}{d t^{2}}=\frac{\lambda}{2 \sqrt{s}} \cdot \frac{d s}{d t}=\frac{\lambda}{2 \sqrt{s}} \cdot \lambda \sqrt{s}=\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2}
$$

Therefore, the acting force $F=\frac{k \lambda^{2}}{2}$ (const).

llm_response:
The problem involves proving that rectilinear motion with speed proportional to the square root of the distance traveled occurs under the action of a constant force. The solution includes a derivation based on Newton's law and involves applying calculus to differentiate and manipulate equations. 

Since this requires demonstrating a property of the motion (i.e., connecting the speed and the resulting force to prove it is constant), it qualifies as a proof problem rather than simply executing a computation.

Thus, the classification for this problem is: 

HARD

This is because it's not merely about performing a calculation, but rather proving a relationship between functions and their properties in the context of motion under a force.

It intercepts segments on the coordinate axes $a = 3 x_{0}, b = 3 y_{1}, c = 3 z_{0}$. These segments are mutually perpendicular edges of the tetrahedron formed by the tangent plane and the coordinate planes. Taking one of these edges as the height of the tetrahedron, we find that its volume $V = \frac{1}{6} a b c = \frac{9}{2} x_{0} y_{t} z_{0} = \frac{9}{2} m^{3}$ (since the point $P$ lies on the given surface) does not depend on the coordinates of the point of tangency $P$. From this, it follows that different tangent planes to the given surface form a tetrahedron of constant (the same) volume with the coordinate planes.

original.problem: 936. What is the greatest rate at which the function $u(M)=\frac{10}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+1}$ can increase as the point $M(x, y, z)$ passes through the point $M_{0}(-1 ; 2 ;-2)$? In what direction should the point $M$ move as it passes through the point $M_{1}(2 ; 0 ; 1)$, so that the function $u(M)$ decreases at the greatest rate?
original.solution:
Solution. The greatest in absolute value the rate of change (increase or decrease) of the function and (M) when the point $M$ passes through the point $P$ numerically equals the modulus of the gradient of the function at point $P$. In this case, the function will increase or decrease at the greatest rate, depending on whether the point $M$ when passing through point $P$ moves in the direction of the gradient of the function at point $P$ or in the directly opposite direction.

Guided by these principles, we find the partial derivatives of the function and and by formula (b) - its gradient at any point:

$$
\operatorname{grad} u=-\frac{20}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+\tilde{z}^{2}+1\right)^{2}}(x \ddot{i}+y \ddot{j}+z k)
$$

Next, we find: 1) $\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{6}\right)=\frac{1}{5}(\bar{i}-2 j+2 \bar{k})$; its modulus, numerically equal to the desired greatest rate of increase of the function $u(M)$ when $M$ passes through $M_{0}$, will be $\left|\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{0}\right)\right|==$ $=\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{2}{5}\right)^{2}}=\frac{3}{5}$.
2) $\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)=-\frac{10}{9} i-\frac{5}{9} k ;$ the desired vector, having the directly opposite direction, will be $-\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)=\frac{10}{9} \ddot{i}+\frac{5}{9} k$. For the function $u(M)$ to decrease at the greatest rate when passing through the point $M_{1}$, the point $M$ must move in the direction of the vector $-\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)$.

llm_response:
This problem involves determining the greatest rate of change of a function and finding the direction in which a point should move for that function to decrease the most rapidly, which requires computing the gradient and its properties. The solution includes the computation of partial derivatives, gradient, and modulus, which can be verified formally.

Thus, I would classify this problem as:
HARD: The problem requires proving properties related to the gradient and directions of movement regarding the rate of change, as opposed to just executing computations.

original.problem:
1091. Solve the equations:
1) $(2 y-3) d x+\left(2 x+3 y^{2}\right) d y=0$
2) $(x+\ln |y|) d x+\left(1+\frac{x}{y}+\sin y\right) d y=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) First, we ensure that the given equation is an equation in total differentials:

$$
P_{y}^{\prime}=(2 y-3)_{y}^{\prime}=2 ; \quad Q_{x}^{\prime}=\left(2 x+3 y^{2}\right)_{x}^{\prime}=2 ; \quad P_{y}^{\prime}=Q_{x}^{\prime}
$$

Then we find the indefinite integrals:

$\int P d x=\int(2 y-3) d x=2 x y-3 x+\varphi(y)$, treating $y$ as a constant, $\int Q d y=\int\left(2 x+3 y^{2}\right) d y=2 x y+y^{3}+\psi(x)$, treating $x$ as a constant.

Taking all known terms from the first result and adding the missing terms, which depend only on $y$, from the second result, we obtain the function $u(x, y)=2 x y-3 x+y^{3}$, the total differential of which is the left-hand side of the given differential equation. By equating it to an arbitrary constant, we obtain the general integral of the given equation:

$$
2 x y-3 x+y^{3}=C
$$[^44]

2) After verifying that the left-hand side of the given equation is the total differential of some function $u(x, y)$:

$$
(x+\ln |y|)_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{y}==\left(1+\frac{x}{y}+\sin y\right)_{x}^{\prime},
$$

we then find this function by integrating each of its partial differentials separately:

$$
\begin{gathered}
u=\int(x+\ln |y|) d x=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+x \ln |y|+\varphi(y) \\
u=\int\left(1+\frac{x}{y}+\sin y\right) d y=y+x \ln |y|-\cos y+\psi(x)
\end{gathered}
$$

Next, we form the final expression for the function $u$ (we add the missing terms, which depend only on $y$, from the second expression to the known terms of the first expression) and, by equating it to an arbitrary constant $C$, we find the general integral of the given equation:

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{2}+x \ln |y|+y-\cos y=C
$$

Check that the following first-order equations are equations in total differentials and solve them.

llm_response:
This problem involves verifying if the given equations are total differentials and solving them to find the general integral of the equations. The solution requires identifying the functions involved and integrating them based on their partial derivatives, which indicates a non-trivial task beyond mere computation of derivatives. Thus, the problem necessitates prooving certain properties about total differentials and the nature of the integrals rather than simply differentiating.

Therefore, this problem can be classified as follows:

HARD: The solution requires proving properties related to total differentials and performing integrations based on those properties, which is more than just straightforward computation.

original.problem: 1162. For which curve is the segment of any tangent, enclosed between the point of tangency and the x-axis, bisected by the y-axis?
original.solution:
Solution. The equation of the tangent at any point $(x, y)$ of the desired curve will be $Y-y=y^{\prime}(X-x)$, where $X, Y-$ are the coordinates of any point on the tangent (Chapter II, § 11).

By setting $Y=0$ in this equation, we find the abscissa $X_{0}$ of the point of intersection of the tangent with the $O x$ axis: $X_{0}=x-\frac{y}{y^{\prime}}$.

According to the condition of the problem, $X_{0}+x=0$, i.e., $2 x-\frac{y}{y^{\prime}}=0$.

Solving this differential equation of the desired curve as an equation with separable variables, we get

$$
2 \frac{d y}{y}=\frac{d x}{x} ; \quad 2 \ln |y|=\ln |x|+\ln C ; \quad y^{2}=C x .
$$

Therefore, the desired curve is a parabola with its vertex at the origin, symmetric with respect to the $O x$ axis.

llm_response:
This problem requires proving the relationship between the properties of the tangent segments of a curve and deriving a differential equation based on the condition provided. The problem does not just involve straightforward computations or evaluations; it requires manipulation of differential equations and properties of curves, which makes it a proof-type problem.

Thus, the classification for this problem is:

HARD: The solution requires proving a property of the curve (that it is a parabola) rather than a simple computation.

original.problem: Example 1. Solve the equation $x y^{\prime}=\sqrt{x^{2}-y^{2}}+y$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's write the equation in the form

$$
y^{\prime}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)^{2}}+\frac{y}{x}
$$

so that the given equation turns out to be homogeneous with respect to $x$ and $y$. Let $u=\frac{y}{x}$, or $y=u x$. Then $y^{\prime}=x u^{\prime}+u$. Substituting the expressions for $y$ and $y^{\prime}$ into the equation, we get

$$
x \frac{d u}{d x}=\sqrt{1-u^{2}} .
$$

Separating the variables:

$$
\frac{d u}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}=\frac{d x}{x}
$$

From this, by integration, we find

$$
\arcsin u=\ln |x|+\ln C_{1}\left(C_{1}>0\right) \text {, or } \quad \arcsin u=\ln C_{1}|x| .
$$

Since $C_{1}|x|= \pm C_{1} x$, denoting $\pm C_{1}=C$, we get $\arcsin u=\ln C x$, where $|\ln C x| \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}$ or $e^{-\pi / 2} \leqslant C x \leqslant e^{\pi / 2}$. Replacing $u$ with $\frac{y}{x}$, we obtain the general integral

$$
\arcsin \frac{y}{x}=\ln C x
$$

From this, the general solution is: $y=x \sin \ln C x$.

When separating the variables, we divided both sides of the equation by the product $x \sqrt{1-u^{2}}$, so we could have lost solutions that make this product zero.

Now let's set $x=0$ and $\sqrt{1-u^{2}}=0$. But $x \neq 0$ due to the substitution $u=\frac{y}{x}$, and from the relation $\sqrt{1-u^{2}}=0$ we get that $1-\frac{y^{2}}{x^{2}}=0$, from which $y= \pm x$. Direct verification shows that the functions $y=-x$ and $y=x$ are also solutions to the given equation.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_a0612bb33256580e6dcdg-028.jpg?height=433&width=427&top_left_y=159&top_left_x=827)

Fig. 12

llm_response:
This problem involves solving a differential equation. The solution process includes transforming the equation into a homogeneous form, making a substitution, separating variables, and integrating. The problem does not merely require computing a derivative or a straightforward verification but instead involves several steps and arguments to arrive at a general solution, including verifying additional solutions that were not captured during the variable separation.

Given this reasoning, I classify this problem as follows:

HARD: The problem requires proving that the general solution encompasses all possible solutions, including specific solutions detected through different approaches in the solution process.

original.problem:
Example 8. Solve the Bernoulli equation

$$
x y^{\prime}+y=y^{2} \ln x
$$
original.solution:
Solution. We apply the method of variation of arbitrary constant. The general solution of the corresponding homogeneous equation $x y^{\prime}+y=0$ is $y=\frac{C}{x}$. We seek the general solution of equation (16) in the form

$$
y=\frac{C(x)}{x}
$$

where $C(x)$ is a new unknown function.

Substituting (17) into (16), we get

$$
C^{\prime}(x)=C^{2}(x) \frac{\ln x}{x^{2}}
$$

To find the function $C(x)$, we obtain a separable variable equation, from which, separating the variables and integrating, we find

$$
\frac{1}{C(x)}=\frac{\ln x}{x}+\frac{1}{x}+C ; \quad C(x)=\frac{x}{1+C x+\ln x}
$$

The general solution of equation (16) is

$$
y=\frac{1}{1+C x+\ln x}
$$

Some nonlinear first-order equations can be reduced to linear equations or Bernoulli equations by a well-chosen change of variables.

llm_response:
The given problem involves solving a Bernoulli equation, which requires the application of a specific method (variation of arbitrary constants) to find the general solution. While the steps towards the solution are provided, the core challenge lies in the application of theory and technique to derive the solution rather than simply executing a straightforward computation.

This problem can be classified as **HARD** because it requires proving the correctness of the method (variation of constants), deriving the solution using separable variables, and confirming the manipulation of equations rather than performing simple derivative computations or standard computations where results are directly obtained. The methods employed are not trivial, and the student must understand underlying properties and the applicable techniques for solutions of differential equations.

original.problem: Example 5. Solve the equation $\left(3 x+2 y+y^{2}\right) d x+\left(x+4 x y+5 y^{2}\right) d y=0$, if its integrating factor has the form $\mu=\varphi\left(x+y^{2}\right)$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $z=x+y^{2}$, then $\mu=\varphi(z)$, and, consequently,

$$
\frac{\partial \ln \mu}{\partial x}=\frac{d \ln \mu}{d z} \cdot \frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial \ln \mu}{d z}, \quad \frac{\partial \ln \mu}{\partial y}=\frac{d \ln \mu}{d z} \cdot \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial \ln \mu}{d z} \cdot 2 y
$$

The equation (5) for finding the integrating factor will have the form

$$
(N-2 M y) \frac{d \ln \mu}{d z}=\frac{\partial M}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial N}{\partial x}, \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{d \ln \mu}{d z}=\frac{(\partial M / \partial y)-(\partial N / \partial x)}{N-2 M y}
$$

Since $M=3 x+2 y+y^{2}, N=x+4 x y+5 y^{2}$, then

$$
\frac{(\partial M / \partial y)-(\partial N / \partial x)}{N-2 M y}=\frac{1}{x+y^{2}}=\frac{1}{z}
$$

and, therefore, $\frac{d \ln \mu}{d z}=\frac{1}{z}$, from which $\mu=z$, i.e., $\mu=x+y^{2}$. Multiplying the given equation by $\mu=x+y^{2}$, we get

$$
\left(3 x^{2}+2 x y+4 x y^{2}+2 y^{3}+y^{4}\right) d x+\left(x^{2}+4 x^{2} y+6 x y^{2}+4 x y^{3}+5 y^{4}\right) d y=0
$$

This is an equation in total differentials and its general integral according to (3) will be

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{x_{0}}^{x}\left(3 x^{2}+2 x y+4 x y^{2}+2 y^{3}+y^{4}\right) d x+\int_{y_{0}}^{y}\left(x_{0}^{2}+4 x_{0}^{2} y+6 x_{0} y^{2}+4 x_{0} y^{3}+5 y^{4}\right) d y=C, \\
& \text { or } \\
& \quad x^{3}+x^{2} y+2 x^{2} y^{2}+2 x y^{3}+x y^{4}+y^{5}=\widehat{C}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\widehat{C}=C+x_{0}^{2} y_{0}+2 x_{0}^{2} y_{0}^{2}+2 x_{0} y_{0}^{3}+x_{0} y_{0}^{4}+y_{0}^{5}+x_{0}^{3}
$$

After some transformations, we will have

$$
(x+y)\left(x+y^{2}\right)^{2}=\widehat{C}
$$

## Problems for Independent Solution

Integrate the following equations:
189. $\left(1-x^{2} y\right) d x+x^{2}(y-x) d y=0$,

$$
\mu=\varphi(x)
$$

190. $\left(x^{2}+y\right) d x-x d y=0$,

$\mu=\varphi(x)$.
191. $\left(x+y^{2}\right) d x-2 x y d y=0$,

$\mu=\varphi(x)$.
192. $\left(2 x^{2} y+2 y+5\right) d x+\left(2 x^{3}+2 x\right) d y=0$,

$\mu=\varphi(x)$.

193. $\left(x^{4} \ln x-2 x y^{3}\right) d x+3 x^{2} y^{2} d y=0$,

## § 8. First-Order Differential Equations Not Solved for the Derivative

$1^{\circ}$. First-order equations of $n$-th degree with respect to $\boldsymbol{y}^{\prime}$. Let us have a differential equation

$$
\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{n}+p_{1}(x, y)\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{n-1}+\ldots+p_{n-1}(x, y) y^{\prime}+p_{n}(x, y)=0
$$

Solve this equation with respect to $y^{\prime}$. Let

$$
y^{\prime}=f_{1}(x, y), \quad y^{\prime}=f_{2}(x, y), \quad \ldots, \quad y^{\prime}=f_{k}(x, y) \quad(k \leqslant n)
$$

- be the real solutions of equation (1).

The general integral of equation (1) will be expressed by the set of integrals:

$$
\Phi_{1}(x, y, C)=0, \quad \Phi_{2}(x, y, C)=0, \quad \ldots, \quad \Phi_{k}(x, y, C)=0
$$

where $\Phi_{i}(x, y, C)=0$ is the integral of the equation $y^{\prime}=f_{i}(x, y)(i=1, \ldots, k)$.

Thus, through each point of the domain where $y^{\prime}$ takes real values, there pass $k$ integral curves.

original.problem:
Example 1. Solve the Riccati equation

$$
y^{\prime}-y^{2}+2 e^{x} y=e^{2 x}+e^{x}
$$

knowing its particular solution $y_{1}=e^{x}$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $y=e^{x}+z(x)$ and substitute into equation (4); we get

$$
\frac{d z}{d x}=z^{2}
$$

from which

$$
-\frac{1}{z}=x-C, \quad \text { or } \quad z=\frac{1}{C-x} .
$$

Thus, the general solution of equation (4) is

$$
y=e^{x}+\frac{1}{C-x}
$$

Remark. Instead of substitution (2), it is often more practical to use the substitution

$$
y=y_{1}(x)+\frac{1}{u(x)}
$$

which immediately reduces the Riccati equation (1) to a linear equation

$$
u^{\prime}-\left(2 a y_{1}+b\right) u=a
$$

2. If two particular solutions of equation (1) are known, then its general integral can be found by a single quadrature.

Let two particular solutions $y_{1}(x)$ and $y_{2}(x)$ of equation (1) be known. Using the fact that the identity

$$
\frac{d y_{1}}{d x} \equiv-a(x) y_{1}^{2}-b(x) y_{1}-c(x)
$$

holds, we can represent equation (1) as

$$
\frac{1}{y-y_{1}} \frac{d\left(y-y_{1}\right)}{d x}=-a(x)\left(y+y_{1}\right)-b(x)
$$

or

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left[\ln y-y_{1}\right]=-a(x)\left(y+y_{1}\right)-b(x)
$$

For the second particular solution $y_{2}(x)$, we similarly find

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left[\ln y-y_{2}\right]=-a(x)\left(y+y_{2}\right)-b(x)
$$

Subtracting equation (6) from equation (5), we get

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left[\ln \frac{y-y_{1}}{y-y_{2}}\right]=a(x)\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)
$$

from which

$$
\frac{y-y_{1}}{y-y_{2}}=C e^{\int a(x)\left[y_{2}(x)-y_{1}(x) \mid d x\right.}
$$

llm_response:
The problem involves solving a Riccati equation, which is a type of differential equation. The solution given requires manipulating the equation through substitution and further calculations. 

The solution process includes deriving a new expression from the original Riccati equation and then integrating to find the general solution. This requires more than straightforward computation; it involves understanding properties of differential equations and methods for solving them. 

However, since it does involve computations based on particular setups rather than just verifying a proof by execution, it does not fit into the "HARD" category, as it does not primarily focus on proving a property of the function.

Thus, the appropriate classification for this problem is:

MEDIUM: The problem involves deriving and solving a differential equation, which is not trivial computation but doesn't hinge on complex proofs.

original.problem: Example 3. Show that the system of functions $e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x, e^{\alpha x} \cos \beta x$, where $\beta \neq 0$, is linearly independent on the interval $-\infty < x < +\infty$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let us determine the values of $\alpha_{1}$ and $\alpha_{2}$ for which the identity

$$
\alpha_{1} e^{\alpha x} \sin \beta x+\alpha_{2} e^{\alpha x} \cos \beta x \equiv 0
$$

holds. Dividing both sides of the identity by $e^{\alpha x} \neq 0$:

$$
\alpha_{1} \sin \beta x+\alpha_{2} \cos \beta x \equiv 0
$$

Substituting $x=0$ into (5), we get $\alpha_{2}=0$ and, therefore, $\alpha_{1} \sin \beta x \equiv 0$; but the function $\sin \beta x$ is not identically zero, so $\alpha_{1}=0$. The identity (5), and thus (4), holds only when $\alpha_{1}=\alpha_{2}=0$, i.e., the given functions are linearly independent in the interval $-\infty<x<+\infty$.

Remark. The linear independence of the trigonometric functions $\sin \beta x, \cos \beta x$ has been proven incidentally.

llm_response:

Proving properties like linear independence requires more than just computation; it involves logical reasoning and justifications.

Thus, the classification for this problem is:

HARD: The solution requires proving a property (linear independence) rather than merely executing a computation.

original.problem:
Example 10. Solve the equation

$$
y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=4 \cos x \cos 3 x+6 \sin ^{2} x
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Using known trigonometric identities, we transform the right-hand side of equation (17) to a "standard" form:

$$
4 \cos x \cos 3 x+6 \sin ^{2} x=2 \cos 4 x-\cos 2 x+3
$$

The original equation (17) can now be written as:

$$
y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=2 \cos 4 x-\cos 2 x+3
$$

The general solution of the homogeneous equation $y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=0$ is

$$
y_{0,0}=C_{1}+\left(C_{2} \cos x+C_{3} \sin x\right) e^{x}
$$

To find a particular solution of equation (18), we use the principle of superposition. For this, we find particular solutions of three equations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=2 \cos 4 x \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=-\cos 2 x \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}-2 y^{\prime \prime}+2 y^{\prime}=3
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the method of undetermined coefficients, we find particular solutions $y_{1}, y_{2}$, and $y_{3}$ of equations (19), (20), and (21) respectively:

$$
y_{1}=\frac{1}{65}\left(\cos 4 x-\frac{7}{4} \sin 4 x\right), \quad y_{2}=\frac{1}{10}\left(\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 x-\cos 2 x\right), \quad y_{3}=\frac{3}{2} x
$$

By the principle of superposition, a particular solution of the non-homogeneous equation (8) is

$$
y_{4, \text {.. }}=\frac{1}{65}\left(\cos 4 x-\frac{7}{4} \sin 4 x\right)+\frac{1}{10}\left(\frac{\sin 2 x}{2}-\cos 2 x\right)+\frac{3}{2} x .
$$

The general solution of the original equation is

$$
y=C_{1}+\left(C_{2} \cos x+C_{3} \sin x\right) e^{x}+
$$

$$
+\frac{1}{65}\left(\cos 4 x-\frac{7}{4} \sin 4 x\right)+\frac{1}{10}\left(\frac{\sin 2 x}{2}-\cos 2 x\right)+\frac{3}{2} x
$$

original.problem: Example 3. Solve the equation $y^{\prime \prime}+y=\frac{1}{\cos x}$.
original.solution:
Solution. The corresponding homogeneous equation will be $y^{\prime \prime}+y=0$. Its characteristic equation $\lambda^{2}+1=0$ has imaginary roots $\lambda_{1}=-i, \lambda_{2}=i$, and the general solution of the homogeneous equation is

$$
y_{0.0}=C_{1} \cos x+C_{2} \sin x
$$

The general solution of the original equation is sought in the form

$$
y=C_{1}(x) \cos x+C_{2}(x) \sin x
$$

where $C_{1}(x)$ and $C_{2}(x)$ are unknown functions of $x$. To find them, we form the system

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\cos x \cdot C_{1}^{\prime}+\sin x \cdot C_{2}^{\prime}(x) & =0 \\
-\sin x \cdot C_{1}^{\prime}(x)+\cos x \cdot C_{2}^{\prime}(x) & =\frac{1}{\cos x}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Solving this system for $C_{1}^{\prime}(x)$ and $C_{2}^{\prime}(x)$:

$$
C_{1}^{\prime}(x)=-\operatorname{tg} x, \quad C_{2}^{\prime}(x)=1
$$

By integration, we find

$$
C_{1}(x)=\ln |\cos x|+\widetilde{C}_{1}, \quad C_{2}(x)=x+\widetilde{C}_{2}
$$

Substituting the expressions for $C_{1}(x)$ and $C_{2}(x)$ into (38), we obtain the general solution of the given equation

$$
y=\widetilde{C}_{1} \cos x+\widetilde{C}_{2} \sin x+\cos x \cdot \ln |\cos x|+x \sin x
$$

Here $\cos x \ln |\cos x|+x \sin x$ is a particular solution of the original non-homogeneous equation.

llm_response:

While this does require some computations and the use of differential equations techniques, the solution primarily involves systematic, methodical steps including integration and manipulation of functions.

However, since it culminates in deriving a particular solution along with a general solution to the non-homogeneous equation, it entails more than just an easy derivation; it requires a proper understanding of the properties of solutions to differential equations and their methods.

Thus, I would classify this problem as:

HARD: The solution involves proving the general form of the solution to a differential equation, utilizing methods specific to the theory of differential equations rather than executing a straightforward computation.

original.problem:
Example 1. Construct the phase plane trajectories for the equation

$$
\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+x=0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\frac{d x}{d t}=v$. Equation (3) takes the form

$$
v \frac{d v}{d x}+x=0, \quad \text { or } \quad \frac{d v}{d x}=-\frac{x}{v} .
$$

The isocline equations for (4): $-\frac{x}{v}=k$. By constructing isoclines corresponding to different values of $k$, we find that the phase trajectories are circles centered at the point $(0,0)$ (Fig. 26).

Note that closed phase trajectories correspond to periodic motions. It is easy to see that in the case of equation (3), we indeed have periodic motion. Solving (3) using the methods outlined above, we find

$$
x(t)=C_{1} \cos t+C_{2} \sin t
$$

$\Delta$

Therefore, this involves a conceptual understanding that goes beyond mere computation.

Classification: HARD

original.problem:
## Example 4. Solve the equation

$$
2 x^{2} y^{\prime \prime}+\left(3 x-2 x^{2}\right) y^{\prime}-(x+1) y=0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Rewrite (27) as

$$
y^{\prime \prime}+\frac{3 x-2 x^{2}}{2 x^{2}} y^{\prime}-\frac{x+1}{2 x^{2}} y=0
$$

or

$$
y^{\prime \prime}+\frac{3-2 x}{2 x} y^{\prime}-\frac{x+1}{2 x^{2}} y=0
$$

The solution $y(x)$ will be sought in the form

$$
y(x)=x^{\rho} \sum_{k=0}^{x} C_{k} x^{k} \quad\left(C_{0} \neq 0\right)
$$

To find $\rho$, we write the defining equation

$$
\rho(\rho-1)+a_{0} \rho+b_{0}=0
$$

where

$$
a_{0}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3-2 x}{2}=\frac{3}{2}, \quad b_{0}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(-\frac{x+1}{2}\right)=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

Thus,

$$
\rho(\rho-1)+\frac{3}{2} \rho-\frac{1}{2}=0, \quad \text { or } \quad \rho^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho-\frac{1}{2}=0
$$

from which $\rho_{1}=\frac{1}{2}, \quad \rho_{2}=-1$.

According to the given rule, we take

$$
y_{1}(x)=x^{1 / 2} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} C_{k} x^{k} \quad(x>0) ; \quad y_{2}(x)=\frac{1}{x} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} A_{k} x^{k}
$$

To find $C_{0}, C_{1}, \ldots, C_{n}, \ldots$, we need to substitute $y_{1}(x)$ and its derivatives $y_{1}^{\prime}(x)$ and $y_{1}^{\prime \prime}(x)$ into equation $(27)$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{1}(x)= & \sum_{k=0}^{x} C_{k} x^{k+(1 / 2)}, \quad y_{1}^{\prime}(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{x}\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right) C_{k} x^{k-(1 / 2)} \\
& y_{1}^{\prime \prime}(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{x}\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(k-\frac{1}{2}\right) C_{k} x^{k-(3 / 2)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $y_{1}(x), y_{1}^{\prime}(x), y_{1}^{\prime \prime}(x)$ into (27) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(k^{2}-\frac{1}{4}\right) C_{k} x^{k-(3 / 2)}+\left(3 x-2 x^{2}\right) \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right) C_{k} x^{k-(1 / 2)}- \\
&-(x+1) \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} C_{k} x^{k+(1 / 2)}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

After transformations, (28) can be rewritten as:

$$
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} k(2 k+3) C_{k} x^{k+(1 / 2)}-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 2(k+1) C_{k} x^{k+(3 / 2)}=0
$$

Since the solution is sought for $x>0$, (29) can be simplified by dividing by $x^{1 / 2}$, which gives

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k(2 k+3) C_{k} x^{k}-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 2(k+1) C_{k} x^{k+1}=0
$$

From this, we find the relation for determining the coefficients

| $x^{\prime}$ | $1 \cdot 5 C_{1}-2 \cdot 1 C_{0}=0$, |
| :--- | :--- |
| $x^{2}$ | $2 \cdot 7 C_{2}-2 \cdot 2 C_{1}=0$, |
| $x^{3}$ | $3 \cdot 9 C_{3}-2 \cdot 3 C_{2}=0$, |
| $\ldots$ | $\ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots$ |
| $x^{n}$ | $n(2 n+3) C_{n}-2 n C_{n-1}=0$, |
| $\ldots$ | $\ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots$ |

Assuming $C_{0}=1$ in the first equation of the relations (31), we get $C_{1}=\frac{2}{5}$. From the second equation, we have $C_{2}=\frac{2^{2}}{5 \cdot 7}$. From the third, $C_{3}=\frac{2^{3}}{5 \cdot 7 \cdot 9}$, and so on. It is easy to see that

$$
C_{n}=\frac{2^{n}}{5 \cdot 7 \cdot 9 \ldots(2 n+3)} \quad(n=1,2,3, \ldots)
$$

Thus,

$$
y_{1}(x)=x^{1 / 2}\left[1+\sum_{k=1}^{x} \frac{(2 x)^{k}}{5 \cdot 7 \cdot 9 \ldots(2 k+3)}\right]
$$

Similarly, we find the coefficients $\boldsymbol{A}_{k}$. It turns out that for $\boldsymbol{A}_{0}=1$

$$
A_{1}=1, \quad A_{2}=\frac{1}{2!}, \quad \ldots, \quad A_{k}=\frac{1}{k!},
$$

so that

$$
y_{2}(x)=\frac{1}{x} \sum_{k=0}^{x} \frac{x^{k}}{k!}, \text { or } y_{2}(x)=\frac{e^{x}}{x} .
$$

The general solution of equation (27) is $y(x)=A y_{1}(x)+B y_{2}(x)$, where $A$ and $B$ are arbitrary constants, and the functions $y_{1}(x)$ and $y_{2}(x)$ are given by formulas (32) and (33).

llm_response:

It requires a number of steps, including rewriting the equation, determining coefficients from certain relations, and substituting to find a general solution. The entire process is more complicated than simply computing derivatives, but it does not require a proof of a property like uniqueness or existence in an abstract sense.

Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

HARD: The solution involves deriving coefficients and manipulating series, which goes beyond mere computation.

original.problem: Example 3. Solve the boundary value problem $x^{2} y^{\prime \prime}+2 x y^{\prime}-6 y=0, y(1)=1$, $y(x)$ is bounded as $x \rightarrow 0$.
original.solution:
Solution. The given equation is an Euler equation. Its general solution has the form $y(x)=\frac{C_{1}}{x^{3}}+C_{2} x^{2}$ (see, for example, 1, item $4^{\circ}, \S$ 15). By the condition, the solution $y(x)$ must be bounded as $x \rightarrow 0$. This requirement will be satisfied if in the general solution we set $C_{1}=0$. Then we will have $y(x)=C_{2} x^{2}$. The boundary condition $y(1)=1$ gives $C_{2}=1$. Therefore, the desired solution is $y=x^{2}$.

$y(0)=0, \quad y^{\prime}(\pi)=0$.

$y(0)=0, \quad y^{\prime}(\pi)=0$.

## § 18. Integration of Differential Equations Using Series

$1^{\circ}$. Expansion of the solution in a power series. This method is particularly convenient for linear differential equations. Let us illustrate its application using a second-order differential equation. Suppose we have a second-order differential equation

$$
y^{\prime \prime}+p(x) y^{\prime}+q(x) y=0
$$

Assume that the coefficients $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ can be represented as series in positive integer powers of $x$, so that equation (1) can be rewritten as

$$
y^{\prime \prime}+\left(a_{0}+a_{1} x+a_{2} x^{2}+\ldots\right) y^{\prime}+\left(b_{0}+b_{1} x+b_{2} x^{2}+\ldots\right) y=0
$$

We will seek the solution of this equation in the form of a power series

$$
y=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_{k} x^{k}
$$

Substituting this expression for $y$ and its derivatives into (2), we get

$$
\sum_{k=2}^{\infty} k(k-1) c_{k} x^{k-2}+\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_{k} x^{k} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k c_{k} x^{k-1}+\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_{k} x^{k} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_{k} x^{k}=0
$$

Multiplying the power series, collecting like terms, and equating the coefficients of all powers of $x$ in the left-hand side (4) to zero, we obtain a series of equations:

$$
\begin{array}{c|l}
x^{0} & 2 \cdot 1 c_{2}+a_{0} c_{1}+b_{0} c_{0}=0 \\
x^{1} & 3 \cdot 2 c_{3}+2 a_{0} c_{2}+a_{1} c_{1}+b_{0} c_{1}+b_{1} c_{0}=0 \\
x^{2} & 4 \cdot 3 c_{4}+3 a_{0} c_{3}+2 a_{1} c_{2}+a_{2} c_{1}+b_{0} c_{2}+b_{1} c_{1}+b_{2} c_{0}=0 \\
\ldots & \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots
\end{array}
$$

Each subsequent equation (5) contains one more unknown coefficient than the previous one. The coefficients $c_{0}$ and $c_{1}$ remain arbitrary and play the role of arbitrary constants. The first equation (5) gives $c_{2}$, the second gives $c_{3}$, the third gives $c_{4}$, and so on. In general, from the $(k+1)$-th equation, we can determine $c_{k+2}$, knowing $c_{0}, c_{1}, \ldots, c_{k+1}$.

Practically, it is convenient to proceed as follows. We will determine two solutions $y_{1}(x)$ and $y_{2}(x)$ according to the above scheme, choosing $c_{0}=1$ and $c_{1}=0$ for $y_{1}(x)$, and $c_{0}=0$ and $c_{1}=1$ for $y_{2}(x)$, which is equivalent to the following initial conditions:

$$
y_{1}(0)=1, \quad y_{1}^{\prime}(0)=0, \quad y_{2}(0)=0, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}(0)=1
$$

Any solution of equation (1) will be a linear combination of the solutions $y_{1}(x)$ and $y_{2}(x)$.

If the initial conditions are of the form $y(0)=A, y^{\prime}(0)=B$, then obviously,

$$
y=A y_{1}(x)+B y_{2}(x)
$$

The following theorem holds.

Theorem. If the series

$$
p(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_{k} x^{k} \quad \text { and } \quad q(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} b_{k} x^{k}
$$

converge for $|x|<R$, then the power series (3) constructed by the above method will also converge for these values of $x$ and will be a solution of equation (1).

In particular, if $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ are polynomials in $x$, then the series (3) will converge for any value of $x$.

original.solution:

$$
y_{1}^{\prime \prime}=y_{1}+e^{y_{2} y_{1}^{\prime}}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=\ln \left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)
$$

A system of ordinary differential equations of the first order of the form

$$
\frac{d x_{k}}{d t}=f_{k}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), \quad k=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

where $t$ is the independent variable; $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ are unknown functions of $t$, is called a normal system.

The number $n$ is called the order of the normal system (3). Two systems of differential equations are called equivalent if they have the same solutions.

Any canonical system (2) can be reduced to an equivalent normal system (3), and the order of these systems will be the same.

Example 3. Solve the system of equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
t \frac{d x}{d t}=-x+y t \\
t^{2} \frac{d y}{d t}=-2 x+y t
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. From the first equation of the system, we find

$$
y=\frac{x}{t}+\frac{d x}{d t}, \quad \text { so that } \quad \frac{d y}{d t}=-\frac{x}{t^{2}}+\frac{1}{t} \cdot \frac{d x}{d t}+\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}} \text {. }
$$

Substituting these expressions for $y$ and $\frac{d y}{d t}$ into the second equation, we get

$$
t^{2} \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+t \frac{d x}{d t}-x=-2 x+x+t \frac{d x}{d t}, \quad \text { or } \quad t^{2} \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=0
$$

Assuming $t \neq 0$, from the last equation we have $\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=0$ and after integration we get $x=C_{1}+C_{2} t$. Now it is easy to find

$$
y=\frac{x}{t}+\frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{C_{1}+C_{2} t}{t}+C_{2}=2 C_{2}+\frac{C_{1}}{t}
$$

The general solution of the given system is

$$
x=C_{1}+C_{2} t, \quad y=\frac{C_{1}}{t}+2 C_{2}, \quad t \neq 0
$$

Remark. Not every system of differential equations can be reduced to a single higher-order equation. For example, $\frac{d x}{d t}=x$, $\frac{d y}{d t}=y$ cannot be reduced to a single second-order equation. Its general solution is $x=C_{1} e^{t}, y=C_{2} e^{t}$.

## § 21. Finding Integrable Combinations. Symmetric Form of a System of Differential Equations

$1^{\circ}$. Finding Integrable Combinations. This method of integrating a system of differential equations

$$
\frac{d x_{k}}{d t}=f_{k}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), \quad k=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

consists of the following: using arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) on the equations of the system (1), we form so-called integrable combinations, i.e., equations of the form

$$
F\left(t, u, \frac{d u}{d t}\right)=0
$$

where $u$ is some function of the unknown functions $x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t), \ldots, x_{n}(t)$. Each integrable combination provides one first integral. If $n$ independent first integrals of the system (1) are found, then its integration is complete; if $m$ independent first integrals are found, where $m<n$, then the system (1) is reduced to a system with a smaller number of unknown functions.

Example 1. Solve the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=2\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\right) t \\
\frac{d x_{2}}{d t}=4 x_{1} x_{2} t
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Adding the two equations term by term, we get

$$
\frac{d\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)}{d t}=\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2} 2 t
$$

from which

$$
-\frac{1}{x_{1}+x_{2}}=t^{2}-C_{1}, \text { or } \frac{1}{x_{1}+x_{2}}+t^{2}=C_{1} \text {. }
$$

Subtracting the two equations term by term, we get

$$
\frac{d\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)}{d t}=2 t\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

from which

$$
\frac{1}{x_{1}-x_{2}}+t^{2}=C_{1}
$$

Thus, two first integrals of the given system are found

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi_{1}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=t^{2}+\frac{1}{x_{1}+x_{2}}=C_{1} \\
& \psi_{2}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=t^{2}+\frac{1}{x_{1}-x_{2}}=C_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

which are independent, since the Jacobian is not zero:

$$
\frac{D\left(\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}\right)}{D\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)}=\left|\begin{array}{ll}
\frac{\partial \psi_{1}}{\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial \psi_{1}}{\partial x_{2}} \\
\frac{\partial \psi_{2}}{\partial x_{1}} & \frac{\partial \psi_{2}}{\partial x_{2}}
\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{1}{\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}} & -\frac{1}{\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}} \\
-\frac{1}{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}} & -\frac{1}{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2}}
\end{array}\right|=-\frac{2}{\left(x_{1}^{2}-x_{2}^{2}\right)^{2}} \neq 0
$$

The general integral of the system (2) is

$$
t^{2}+\frac{1}{x_{1}+x_{2}}=C_{1}, \quad t^{2}+\frac{1}{x_{1}-x_{2}}=C_{2}
$$

Solving the system (3) for the unknown functions, we get the general solution of the system (2):

$$
x_{1}=\frac{C_{1}+C_{2}-2 t^{2}}{2\left(C_{1}-t^{2}\right)\left(C_{2}-t^{2}\right)}, \quad x_{2}=\frac{C_{2}-C_{1}}{2\left(C_{1}-t^{2}\right)\left(C_{2}-t^{2}\right)} .
$$

$$
original.solution:
Solution. Multiplying the numerators and denominators of the fractions in system (23) by $3, 4, 5$ respectively and adding the numerators and denominators, we obtain, by (19),

$$
\frac{3 d t}{12 y-15 x}=\frac{4 d x}{20 t-12 y}=\frac{5 d y}{15 x-20 t}=\frac{3 d t+4 d x+5 d y}{0}
$$

(here $\lambda_{1}=3, \lambda_{2}=4, \lambda_{3}=5$). From this, $3 d t+4 d x+5 d y$ or $d(3 t+4 x+5 y)=0$, which means $3 t+4 x+5 y=C_{1}$ - this is the first integral of system (23).

Multiplying the numerators and denominators of the fractions in system (23) by $\lambda_{1}=2 t, \lambda_{2}=2 x, \lambda_{3}=2 y$ respectively and adding the numerators and denominators, we obtain, by (19),

$$
\frac{2 t d t}{8 y t-10 x t}=\frac{2 x d x}{10 t x-6 y x}=\frac{2 y d y}{6 x y-8 t y}=\frac{2 t d t+2 x d x+2 y d y}{0}
$$

from which

$$
2 t d x+2 x d x+2 y d y=0, \quad \text { or } \quad d\left(t^{2}+x^{2}+y^{2}\right)=0,
$$

and, therefore, the second first integral will be $t^{2}+x^{2}+y^{2}=C_{2}$.

The combination of the first integrals, which are independent, gives the general integral of system (23):

$$
3 t+4 x+5 y=C_{1}, \quad t^{2}+x^{2}+y^{2}=C_{2} .
$$

Thus, system (23) is solved.

## § 22. Integration of Homogeneous Linear Systems with Constant Coefficients. Euler's Method

A homogeneous linear system with constant coefficients is a system of differential equations of the form

$$
\frac{d x_{i}}{d t}=\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{i k} x_{k}(t), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

where the coefficients $a_{i k}$ are constants, and $x_{k}(t)$ are the unknown functions of $t$.

The system (1) can be briefly written as a single matrix equation

$$
\frac{d X}{d t}=A X
$$

where

$$
A=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
a_{11} & a_{12} & a_{1 n} \\
a_{21} & a_{22} & a_{2 n} \\
\cdots \cdots & \ldots \ldots & \ldots \\
a_{n 1} & a_{n 2} & a_{n n}
\end{array}\right), \quad X=\left(\begin{array}{c}
x_{1}(t) \\
x_{2}(t) \\
\vdots \\
x_{n}(t)
\end{array}\right), \quad \frac{d X}{d t}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{d x_{1}}{d t} \\
\frac{d x_{2}}{d t} \\
\vdots \\
\frac{d x_{n}}{d t}
\end{array}\right)
$$

A column matrix

$$

x_{n}^{(1)}(t) \\
x_{n}^{(2)}(t) \\
\vdots \\
x_{n}^{(n)}(t)
\end{array}\right)
$$

(here in the notation $x_{i}^{k}$ the lower index indicates the number of the solution, and the upper index indicates the function number in the solution) is called fundamental on the interval $(a, b)$ if its Wronskian determinant

W(t) \equiv W\left(X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots X_{n}\right)=\left|\begin{array}{cccc}

$$

for all $t \in(a, b)$.

Example 3. Solve the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=2 x+y \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=4 y-x
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The characteristic equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2-r & 1 \\
-1 & 4-r
\end{array}\right|=0, \text { or } r^{2}-6 r+9=0
$$

has a multiple root $r_{1}=r_{2}=3$.

The solution should be sought in the form

$$
x=\left(\lambda_{1}+\mu_{1} t\right) e^{3 t}, \quad y=\left(\lambda_{2}+\mu_{2} t\right) e^{3 t}
$$

Substituting (13) into the first equation of the system (12), we get

$$
3\left(\lambda_{1}+\mu_{1} t\right)+\mu_{1}=2\left(\lambda_{1}+\mu_{1} t\right)+\left(\lambda_{2}+\mu_{2} t\right) .
$$

Equating the coefficients of the same powers of $t$ on the left and right sides of (14), we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 \lambda_{1}+\mu_{1} & =2 \lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}, \\
3 \mu_{1} & =2 \mu_{1}+\mu_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

from which

$$
\lambda_{2}=\lambda_{1}+\mu_{1}, \quad \mu_{2}=\mu_{1}
$$

The quantities $\lambda_{1}$ and $\mu_{1}$ remain arbitrary. Denoting them by $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ respectively, we obtain the general solution of the system (12):

$$
x=\left(C_{1}+C_{2} t\right) e^{3 t}, \quad y=\left(C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{2} t\right) e^{3 t}
$$

Remark. It is easy to verify that if (13) is substituted into the second equation of the system (12), we will get the same result (15). Indeed, from the equality

$$
\mu_{2}+3\left(\lambda_{2}+\mu_{2} t\right)=4\left(\lambda_{2}+\mu_{2} t\right)-\left(\lambda_{1}+\mu_{1} t\right)
$$

we get two relations for determining $\lambda_{2}$ and $\mu_{2}$ in terms of $\lambda_{1}$ and $\mu_{1}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu_{2}+3 \lambda_{2} & =4 \lambda_{2}-\lambda_{1}, \\
3 \mu_{2} & =4 \mu_{2}-\mu_{1},
\end{aligned}
$$

from which $\lambda_{2}=\lambda_{1}+\mu_{2}, \mu_{2}=\mu_{1}$.

Example 2. Solve the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=x-5 y \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=2 x-y
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let's write down the system for determining $\lambda$ and $\mu$:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
(1-r) \lambda-5 \mu=0 \\
2 \lambda-(1+r) \mu=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

The characteristic equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
1-r & -5 \\
2 & -1-r
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

has roots $r_{1}=3 i, r_{2}=-3 i$. Substituting $r_{1}=3 i$ into (8), we get two equations for determining $\lambda_{1}$ and $\mu_{1}$:

$$
(1-3 i) \lambda_{1}-5 \mu_{1}=0, \quad 2 \lambda_{1}-(1+3 i) \mu_{1}=0
$$

one of which is a consequence of the other (due to the fact that the determinant of system (8) is zero).

Let's take $\lambda_{1}=5, \mu_{1}=1-3 i$, then the first particular solution is written as:

$$
x_{1}=5 e^{3 i t}, \quad y_{1}=(1-3 i) e^{3 i t} .
$$

Similarly, substituting the root $r_{2}=-3 i$ into (8), we find the second particular solution:

$$
x_{2}=5 e^{-3 i t}, \quad y_{2}=(1+3 i) e^{-3 i t}
$$

Let's transition to a new fundamental system of solutions:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\tilde{x}_{1}=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, & \tilde{x}_{2}=\frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{2 i} \\
\tilde{y}_{1}=\frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}, & \tilde{y}_{2}=\frac{y_{1}-y_{2}}{2 i}
\end{array}
$$

Using the known Euler's formula $e^{ \pm \text {ait }}=\cos \alpha t \pm i \sin \alpha t$, from (9), (10), and (11) we get

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\widetilde{x}_{1}=5 \cos 3 t, & \widetilde{x}_{2}=5 \sin 3 t, \\
\bar{y}_{1}=\cos 3 t+3 \sin 3 t, & \bar{y}_{2}=\sin 3 t-3 \cos 3 t .
\end{array}
$$

The general solution of system (7) will be

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=C_{1} \tilde{x}_{1}+C_{2} \tilde{x}_{2}=5 C_{1} \cos 3 t+5 C_{2} \sin 3 t \\
& y=C_{1} \tilde{y}_{1}+C_{2} \widetilde{y}_{2}=C_{1}(\cos 3 t+3 \sin 3 t)+C_{2}(\sin 3 t-3 \cos 3 t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark. Having found the first particular solution (9), we could have immediately written the general solution of system (7) using the formulas

$$
x=C_{1} \operatorname{Re} x_{1}+C_{2} \operatorname{Im} x_{1}, \quad y=C_{1} \operatorname{Re} y_{1}+C_{2} \operatorname{Im} y_{1}
$$

where $\operatorname{Re} z$ and $\operatorname{Im} z$ denote the real and imaginary parts of the complex number $z$, i.e., if $z=a+b i$, then $\operatorname{Re} z=a, \operatorname{Im} z=b$.

V. The case of multiple roots.

Example 3. Based on the definition of Lyapunov stability, show that the solution of the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=-y \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=x
\end{array}\right.
$$

satisfying the initial conditions $x(0)=0, y(0)=0$, is stable.
original.solution:
Solution. The solution of system (11) that satisfies the given initial conditions is $x(t) \equiv 0, y(t) \equiv 0$. Any solution of this system that satisfies the conditions $x(0)=x_{0}, y(0)=y_{0}$ has the form

$$
x(t)=x_{0} \cos t - y_{0} \sin t, \quad y(t)=x_{0} \sin t + y_{0} \cos t
$$

Take any $\varepsilon > 0$ and show that there exists $\delta(\varepsilon) > 0$ such that when $\left|x_{0} - 0\right| < \delta, \left|y_{0} - 0\right| < \delta$, the inequalities

$$
|x(t) - 0| = \left|x_{0} \cos t - y_{0} \sin t\right| < \varepsilon, \quad |y(t) - 0| = \left|x_{0} \sin t + y_{0} \cos t\right| < \varepsilon
$$

hold for all $t \geqslant 0$.

This will mean, according to the definition, that the zero solution $x(t) \equiv 0$, $y(t) \equiv 0$ of system (11) is stable in the sense of Lyapunov. We have, obviously,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|x_{0} \cos t - y_{0} \sin t\right| \leqslant \left|x_{0} \cos t\right| + \left|y_{0} \sin t\right| \leqslant \left|x_{0}\right| + \left|y_{0}\right| \\
& \left|x_{0} \sin t + y_{0} \cos t\right| \leqslant \left|x_{0} \sin t\right| + \left|y_{0} \cos t\right| \leqslant \left|x_{0}\right| + \left|y_{0}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t$. Therefore, if $\left|x_{0}\right| + \left|y_{0}\right| < \varepsilon$, then

$$
\left|x_{0} \cos t - y_{0} \sin t\right| < \varepsilon, \quad \left|x_{0} \sin t + y_{0} \cos t\right| < \varepsilon
$$

for all $t$.

Thus, if, for example, we take $\delta(\varepsilon) = \varepsilon / 2$, then when $\left|x_{0}\right| < \delta$ and $\left|y_{0}\right| < \delta$, the inequalities (13) will hold for all $t \geqslant 0$ due to (12), i.e., indeed the zero solution of system (11) is stable in the sense of Lyapunov, but this stability is not asymptotic.

Theorem. The solutions of the system of linear differential equations

$$
\frac{d x_{i}}{d t} = \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{i j}(t) x_{j} + f_{i}(t), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

are either all simultaneously stable or all unstable.

This statement is not true for nonlinear systems, some solutions of which may be stable while others are unstable.

Example 4. Solve the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=x+2 y+16 t e^{t} \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=2 x-2 y
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The characteristic equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
1-\lambda & 2 \\
2 & -2-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0, \text { or } \quad \lambda^{2}+\lambda-6=0
$$

The roots of the characteristic equation are $\lambda_{1}=2, \lambda_{2}=-3$. The general solution of the homogeneous system corresponding to system (15) is:

$$
\tilde{x}=2 C_{1} e^{2 t}+C_{2} e^{-3 t}, \quad \tilde{y}=C_{1} e^{2 t}-2 C_{2} e^{-3 t}
$$

We seek a particular solution of the non-homogeneous system of equations (15) in the form

$$
x_{\text {p }}=(A t+B) e^{t}, \quad y_{\text {p }}=(M t+N) e^{t}
$$

Substituting (16) into (15) and canceling $e^{t}$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
A t+B+A & =A t+B+2 M t+2 N+16 t \\
M t+N+M & =2 A t+2 B-2 M t-2 N
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $A=-12, B=-13, M=-8, N=-6$. Therefore,

$$
x_{\text {p }}=-(12 t+13) e^{t}, \quad y_{\text {p }}=-(8 t+6) e^{t}
$$

The general solution of the original system is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\tilde{x}+x_{p}=2 C_{1} e^{2 t}+C_{2} e^{-3 t}-(12 t+13) e^{t} \\
& y=\tilde{y}+y_{p}=C_{1} e^{2 t}-2 C_{2} e^{-3 t}-(8 t+6) e^{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=a_{1} x+b_{1} y+f_{1}(t) \\

Multiply the second equation by some number $\lambda$ and add it term by term to the first equation:

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) x+\left(b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}\right) y+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Rewrite the last equation as

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right)\left(x+\frac{b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}}{a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}} y\right)+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Choose the number $\lambda$ such that

$$
\frac{b_{1}+\lambda b_{2}}{a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}}=\lambda
$$

Then (18) reduces to an equation linear in $x+\lambda y$

$$
\frac{d(x+\lambda y)}{d t}=\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right)(x+\lambda y)+f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)
$$

Integrating which, we get

x+\lambda y=e^{\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) t}\left\{C+\int\left[f_{1}(t)+\lambda f_{2}(t)\right] e^{-\left(a_{1}+\lambda a_{2}\right) t} d t\right\}
$$

If equation (19) has distinct real roots $\lambda_{1}$ and $\lambda_{2}$, then from (20) we obtain two first integrals of system (17), and thus the integration of this system is complete.

Example 3. Will the equilibrium point $(0,0)$ of the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{d x}{d t}=-x+z \\
\frac{d y}{d t}=-2 y-z \\
\frac{d z}{d t}=y-z
\end{array}\right.
$$

be stable?
original.solution:
Solution. We form the characteristic equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
-1-\lambda & 0 & 1 \\
0 & -2-\lambda & -1 \\
0 & 1 & -1-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or $(1+\lambda)\left(\lambda^{2}+3 \lambda+3\right)=0$. The roots of this equation are $\lambda_{1}=-1, \lambda_{2,3}=-\frac{3}{2} \pm i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$. These roots have negative real parts. Therefore, the equilibrium point of the given system is asymptotically stable.

## § 27. The Method of Lyapunov Functions

The method of Lyapunov functions consists in directly investigating the stability of the equilibrium position of the system

$$
\frac{d x_{i}}{d t}=f_{i}\left(t, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

using a suitably chosen function $V\left(t, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ - the Lyapunov function, and this is done without first finding the solutions of the system.

We will limit ourselves to considering autonomous systems

$$
\frac{d x_{i}}{d t}=f_{i}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

for which $x_{i} \equiv 0, i=1,2, \ldots, n$, is an equilibrium point.

A function $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, defined in some neighborhood of the origin, is called sign-definite (definitely positive or definitely negative) if it in the domain

$$
\left|x_{i}\right| \leqslant h, \quad i=1,2, \ldots, n
$$

where $h$ is a sufficiently small positive number, can take values of only one definite sign and is zero only when $x_{1}=x_{2}=\ldots=x_{n}=0$. For example, in the case $n=3$ the functions

$$
V=x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad V=x_{1}^{2}+2 x_{1} x_{2}+2 x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}
$$

will be definitely positive, and here the value of $h>0$ can be taken arbitrarily large.

A function $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is called sign-constant (positive or negative) if it in the domain (2) can take values of only one definite sign, but can be zero even when $x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\ldots+x_{n}^{2} \neq 0$. For example, the function

$$
V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right)=x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+2 x_{1} x_{2}+x_{3}^{2}
$$

will be sign-constant (positive). Indeed, the function $V\left(x_{1}\right.$, $x_{2}, x_{3}$ ) can be written as: $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\right)=\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}+x_{3}^{2}$, from which it is clear that it can be zero even when $x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2} \neq 0$, namely when $x_{3}=0$ and for any $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ such that $x_{1}=-x_{2}$.

Let $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be a differentiable function of its arguments and let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be some functions of time, satisfying the system of differential equations (1). Then for the total derivative of the function $V$ with respect to time, we will have:

$$
\frac{d V}{d t}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\partial V}{\partial x_{i}} \cdot \frac{d x_{i}}{d t}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\partial V}{\partial x_{i}} f_{i}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
$$

The quantity $\frac{d V}{d t}$, determined by formula (3), is called the total derivative of the function $V$ with respect to time, composed according to the system (1).

Theorem 1 (Lyapunov's theorem on stability). If for the system of differential equations (1) there exists a sign-definite function $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ (the Lyapunov function), the total derivative $\frac{d V}{d t}$ of which with respect to time, composed according to the system (1), is a sign-constant function, of a sign opposite to that of $V$, or identically equal to zero, then the equilibrium point $x_{i}=0, i=1,2, \ldots, n$, of the system (1) is stable.

Theorem 2 (Lyapunov's theorem on asymptotic stability). If for the system of differential equations (1) there exists a sign-definite function $V\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, the total derivative of which with respect to time, composed according to the system (1), is also a sign-definite function, of a sign opposite to that of $V$, then the equilibrium point $x_{i}=0$ of the system (1) is asymptotically stable.

Therefore, this problem best fits the classification of HARD, as it necessitates substantial reasoning and proof around properties of the system, rather than straightforward calculations.

original.problem: 48. An electric lamp is suspended on a pulley above the center of a round table. At what height should this lamp be fixed to obtain the greatest illumination at the edges of the table?
original.solution:
48. Illuminance is given by the formula $E=\frac{k \sin \alpha}{A C^{2}}$, where $k$ is the proportionality coefficient; $A C$ is the distance from the lamp to the edge of the table. But $A C=\frac{R}{\cos \alpha}$, where $\alpha$ is the angle of inclination of $A C$ to the plane of the table. Then

$$
E=\frac{k \sin \alpha \cos ^{2} \alpha}{R^{2}} ;\left(\frac{E R^{2}}{2 k}\right)^{2}=\left(1-\cos ^{2} \alpha\right) \frac{\cos ^{2} \alpha}{2} \cdot \frac{\cos ^{2} \alpha}{2}
$$

Since the sum of the three factors is constant and equal to 1, the best illumination at point $C$ will be when $1-\cos \alpha=\frac{\cos ^{2} \alpha}{2}$, from which $\cos \alpha=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}, h=R \operatorname{tg} \alpha \approx 0.7 R$.

## 11.4. Sums of Sines and Cosines Related to Regular Polygons

In solving the problems of this section, the following geometric problem is useful.
original.solution: 11.17. Answer: 63. First, note that the number of positive roots is equal to the number of negative roots, and there is also a root 0. Therefore, it is sufficient to verify that the number of positive roots is 31. If $\sin x = x / 100$, then $|x| = 100|\sin x| \leqslant 100$. Consider the graphs of the functions $y = x / 100$ and $y = \sin x$. The segment of the $O x$ axis from 0 to 100 contains 15 segments of length $2 \pi$ and one segment of length less than $2 \pi$. By examining the specified graphs, it is easy to see that on the first segment of length $2 \pi$ there is one root of the given equation, and on each of the other 14 segments of length $2 \pi$ there are two roots. Calculations show that the length of the last segment is greater than $\pi$, so there are also two roots on it. In total, we get 31 positive roots.

25.12. Prove that any bounded sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ contains a convergent subsequence $\left\{a_{n_{k}}\right\}$, i.e., one can choose a strictly increasing sequence of natural numbers $n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}, \ldots$ such that the sequence $\left\{b_{k}\right\}$, where $b_{k}=a_{n_{k}}$, converges.

A sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is called increasing (non-decreasing) if $a_{n+1}>a_{n}\left(a_{n+1} \geqslant a_{n}\right)$ for all $n$.

A sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is called bounded from above if one can choose a number $c$ such that $a_{n} \leqslant c$ for all $n$.

original.problem: 26.28. Prove that a function $f$, defined on the interval $[a, b]$, is of bounded variation if and only if it can be represented as the difference of two non-decreasing functions.
original.solution:
26.28. It is clear that if the function $g$ is non-decreasing or non-increasing, then $\operatorname{Var}_{a}^{b}(g)=|g(a)-g(b)|$; in particular, $g$ is a function of bounded variation. It is also clear that if $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ are functions of bounded variation, then $f=g_{1}+g_{2}$ is also a function of bounded variation.

Consider the sum $v=\sum_{k=0}^{m}\left|f\left(x_{k+1}\right)-f\left(x_{k}\right)\right|$. Let $p$ be the sum of those terms for which $f\left(x_{k+1}\right)-f\left(x_{k}\right)>0$, and $(-n)$ be the sum of those terms for which $f\left(x_{k+1}\right)-f\left(x_{k}\right)<0$. Then $v=p+n$ and $f(b)-f(a)=p-n$, so

$$
v=2 p+f(a)-f(b)=2 n+f(b)-f(a)
$$

Let $V, P$ and $N$ be the exact upper bounds of the numbers $v, p$ and $n$ for all sets of points $x_{0}=a<x_{1}<\ldots<x_{m}<b=x_{m+1}$. Similarly, define the numbers $V(x), P(x)$ and $N(x)$ by replacing the interval $[a, b]$ with the interval $[a, x]$. It is clear that $P(x)$ and $N(x)$ are non-decreasing functions on the interval $[a, b]$. It is also clear that

$$
V(x)=2 P(x)+f(a)-f(x)=2 N(x)+f(x)-f(a),
$$

so $f(x)=f(a)+P(x)-N(x)$. Both functions $f(a)+P(x)$ and $N(x)$ are non-decreasing.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a property related to functions of bounded variation and their representation as differences of non-decreasing functions. The solution involves establishing the equivalence through rigorous mathematical reasoning and proof, which does not boil down to a straightforward computation.

Since the problem requires proving a specific property (the characterization of functions of bounded variation), it does not fit into categories like EASY or MEDIUM, where computations are central. Instead, it aligns more with establishing a mathematical theorem based on definitions and properties of functions, which requires reasoning rather than mere calculation.

Thus, the appropriate classification for this problem is:

**HARD**. 

The solution is a proving task that verifies a significant property about a functional analysis concept.

28.40. The function $f(x)$ is differentiable on the interval $[a, b]$.

a) Prove that this function is non-decreasing (on this interval) if and only if $f^{\prime}(x) \geqslant 0$ for any point $x$ in the interval $(a, b)$.

b) Prove that if $f^{\prime}(x) \geqslant 0$ for any point $x$ in the interval $(a, b)$ and there does not exist an interval $[p, q]$ contained in $[a, b]$, in all points of which $f^{\prime}$ is zero, then the function $f(x)$ is increasing.
original.solution:
28.40. a) It is evident from the definition of the derivative that \( f'(x) \geqslant 0 \) for a non-decreasing function \( f(x) \).

Suppose now that \( f'(x) \geqslant 0 \) for any point \( x \) in the interval \((a, b)\). Take two points \( x \) and \( y \) on the segment \([a, b]\) such that \( x < y \). Apply Lagrange's theorem (problem 28.38) to the segment \([x, y]\). As a result, we get that \( f(y) - f(x) = f'(z)(y - x) \) for some point \( z \) in the interval \((x, y)\). By the condition, \( f'(z) \geqslant 0 \), therefore \( f(y) \geqslant f(x) \).
b) According to part a), the function \( f(x) \) is non-decreasing. Choose two points \( x \) and \( y \) on the segment \([a, b]\) such that \( x < y \). Then for any point \( z \) on the segment \([x, y]\), the inequalities \( f(x) \leqslant f(z) \leqslant f(y) \) hold. Therefore, if \( f(x) = f(y) \), then the function \( f \) is constant on the segment \([x, y]\). But then \( f' \) is zero on this segment, which contradicts the condition.

original.problem:
28.78. Let $a$ be a fixed number, and $f(x)$ be a function having derivatives up to order $n+1$ inclusive for any $x$ between $a$ and $b$ (for some $b$). Prove that if the number $x$ is between $a$ and $b$ and if

$T(x)=f(a)+\frac{f^{\prime}(a)}{1!}(x-a)+\frac{f^{\prime \prime}(a)}{2!}(x-a)^{2}+\ldots+\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x-a)^{n}$, then

$$
f(x)-T(x)=\frac{f^{(n+1)}(\vartheta)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}
$$

for some $\vartheta$ between $a$ and $x$ (Taylor's formula).
original.solution:
28.78. It is clear that $T(a)=f(a)$. Further,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& T^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(a)+\frac{f^{\prime \prime}(a)}{1!}(x-a)+\ldots+\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-1)!}(x-a)^{n-1} \\
& T^{\prime \prime}(x)=f^{\prime \prime}(a)+\frac{f^{\prime \prime \prime}(a)}{1!}(x-a)+\ldots+\frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{(n-2)!}(x-a)^{n-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
T^{(n)}(x) & =f^{(n)}(a) \\
T^{(n+1)}(x) & =0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $T^{\prime}(a)=f^{\prime}(a), T^{\prime \prime}(a)=f^{\prime \prime}(a), \ldots, T^{(n)}(a)=f^{(n)}(a)$ and $T^{(n+1)}(x) = 0$.

Consider the auxiliary function $\varphi(x)=f(x)-T(x)$. For it, $\varphi(a)=\varphi^{\prime}(a)=\varphi^{\prime \prime}(a)=\ldots=\varphi^{(n)}(a)=0$ and $\varphi^{(n+1)}(x)=f^{(n+1)}(x)$. Consider another auxiliary function $\psi(x)=\frac{(x-a)^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}$. For it, $\psi(a)=\psi^{\prime}(a)=\psi^{\prime \prime}(a)=\ldots=\psi^{(n)}(a)=0$ and $\psi^{(n+1)}(x)=1$. Moreover, the function $\psi$ and its derivatives up to the $(n+1)$-th, inclusive, do not vanish at points other than $a$.

Fix a point $x \neq a$. From the equalities $\varphi(a)=\psi(a)=0$ it follows that $\frac{\varphi(x)}{\psi(x)}=\frac{\varphi(x)-\varphi(a)}{\psi(x)-\psi(a)}$. Therefore, by the Cauchy theorem (problem 28.45), there exists a point $x_{1}$ between $a$ and $x$ for which $\frac{\varphi(x)}{\psi(x)}=\frac{\varphi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}{\psi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}$. From the equalities $\varphi^{\prime}(a)=\psi^{\prime}(a)=0$ it follows that $\frac{\varphi^{\prime}(x)}{\psi^{\prime}(x)}=\frac{\varphi^{\prime}(x)-\varphi^{\prime}(a)}{\psi^{\prime}(x)-\psi^{\prime}(a)}$. Therefore, by the Cauchy theorem, there exists a point $x_{2}$ between $a$ and $x_{1}$ (and hence between $a$ and $x$), for which $\frac{\varphi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}{\psi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}=\frac{\varphi^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right)}{\psi^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right)}$. Continuing these arguments, we get

$$
\frac{\varphi(x)}{\psi(x)}=\frac{\varphi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}{\psi^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)}=\frac{\varphi^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right)}{\psi^{\prime \prime}\left(x_{2}\right)}=\ldots=\frac{\varphi^{(n+1)}\left(x_{n+1}\right)}{\psi^{(n+1)}\left(x_{n+1}\right)}
$$

where the point $x_{n+1}$ lies between $a$ and $x$.

Recall that $\varphi^{(n+1)}(x)=f^{(n+1)}(x)$ and $\psi^{(n+1)}(x)=1$. Let $\vartheta = x_{n+1}$. Then $\frac{\varphi(x)}{\psi(x)}=f^{(n+1)}(\vartheta)$, i.e., $f(x)-T(x)=\frac{f^{(n+1)}(\vartheta)}{(n+1)!}(x-a)^{n+1}$.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving the Taylor's theorem, which asserts that if a function \( f \) is \( n+1 \) times differentiable on an interval, then the difference between the function and its Taylor polynomial can be expressed in terms of the \((n+1)\)-th derivative at some point \( \vartheta \) within the interval. The solution involves a significant amount of reasoning, particularly employing the properties of derivatives and applying the Cauchy Mean Value Theorem multiple times to arrive at the final expression.

Since the task is to verify a theorem and involves proving properties of functions rather than just performing calculations, it requires a level of rigor beyond basic calculations. 

Therefore, this problem falls under the category:

HARD: It requires proving a property related to Taylor's formula, not just executing a computation.

29.42. Using the inequalities $t-\frac{t^{3}}{6} \leqslant \sin t$ and $\cos t \leqslant 1-\frac{t^{2}}{2} + \frac{t^{4}}{24}$ (Problem 29.41), it follows from the first inequality that

$$
\left(\frac{\sin t}{t}\right)^{3} \geqslant \left(1-\frac{t^{2}}{6}\right)^{3}=1-\frac{t^{2}}{2}+\frac{t^{4}}{12}-\frac{t^{6}}{216}
$$

Therefore, it is sufficient to prove that $1-\frac{t^{2}}{2}+\frac{t^{4}}{12}-\frac{t^{6}}{216}>1-\frac{t^{2}}{2}+\frac{t^{4}}{24}$. This inequality is equivalent to $\frac{t^{4}}{24}-\frac{t^{6}}{216}>0$, i.e., $t^{2}<9$. For $0<t \leqslant \pi / 2$, this inequality holds.

30.18. Identity

$$
\frac{1}{1+t}=1-t+t^{2}-\ldots+(-1)^{n-1} t^{n-1}+\frac{(-1)^{n} t^{n}}{1+t}
$$

shows that if $x>-1$, then

$$
\ln (1+x)=\int_{0}^{x} \frac{d t}{1+t}=x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{x^{3}}{3}-\ldots+(-1)^{n-1} \frac{x^{n}}{n}+(-1)^{n} R_{n}
$$

where $R_{n}=\int_{0}^{x} \frac{t^{n}}{1+t} d t$

If $0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1$, then $0 \leqslant R_{n} \leqslant \int_{0}^{x} t^{n} d t=\frac{x^{n}}{n+1} \leqslant \frac{1}{n+1} \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

If $-1 \leqslant x<0$, then we make the substitution $x=-y$. Then we get $R_{n}=$ $=(-1)^{n+1} \int_{0}^{y} \frac{t^{n}}{1-t} d t$, so $\left|R_{n}\right| \leqslant \frac{1}{1-y} \int_{0}^{y} t^{n} d t=\frac{y^{n}}{(1-y)(n+1)} \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

original.problem: 36.10. Prove that $D(\operatorname{Ln}(f))=f^{-1} D(f)$.
original.solution:
36.10. It is clear that $D(\operatorname{Ln}(f))=D\left(g-\frac{1}{2} g^{2}+\frac{1}{3} g^{3}-\ldots\right)$. Using the fact that each coefficient of the formal series $\operatorname{Ln}(f)$ is defined by a finite sum, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D\left(g-\frac{1}{2} g^{2}+\frac{1}{3} g^{3}-\ldots\right)=D(g)-\frac{1}{2} D\left(g^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{3} D\left(g^{3}\right)-\ldots= \\
& =D(g)-g D(g)+g^{2} D(g)-\ldots=D(g)\left(1-g+g^{2}-\ldots\right)= \\
& =D(g)(1+g)^{-1}=f^{-1} D(f)
\end{aligned}
$$

since $D(f)=D(f-1)=D(g)$.

llm_response:
This problem requires proving the relationship involving the derivative of the natural logarithm function of another function \( f \). The solution provided involves the manipulation of formal series and utilizes properties of derivatives.

original.problem: 32.7. Prove that the roots of the derivative of a polynomial $P$ belong to the convex hull of the roots of the polynomial $P$ itself (Gauss-Lucas theorem).
original.solution:
32.7. Let $P(z)=\left(z-z_{1}\right) \ldots\left(z-z_{n}\right)$. It is easy to verify that

$$
\frac{P^{\prime}(z)}{P(z)}=\frac{1}{z-z_{1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{z-z_{n}}
$$

Suppose that $P^{\prime}(w)=0, P(w) \neq 0$ and $w$ does not belong to the convex hull of the points $z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}$. Then a line can be drawn through the point $w$ that does not intersect the convex hull of the points $z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}$. Therefore, the vectors $w-z_{1}, \ldots, w-z_{n}$ lie in the same half-plane defined by this line. Consequently, the vectors $\frac{1}{w-z_{1}}, \ldots, \frac{1}{w-z_{n}}$ also lie in the same half-plane, since $\frac{1}{z}=\frac{\bar{z}}{|z|^{2}}$. Therefore, $\frac{P(z)}{P^{\prime}(z)}=\frac{1}{z-z_{1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{z-z_{n}} \neq 0$. This is a contradiction. Therefore, $w$ belongs to the convex hull of the roots of the polynomial $P$.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a property about the roots of the derivative of a polynomial and connecting it to the roots of the polynomial itself, specifically demonstrating a geometric relationship. Since it requires a full proof of a theorem (Gauss-Lucas theorem) rather than merely computing or verifying a specific function or property, this falls into the category of properties that require proof rather than computation.

Justification: The solution necessitates a series of logical deductions and geometric arguments rather than a straightforward computation, which is characteristic of a hard problem.

Classification: HARD
